## Doctrinal framework in the Westminster Confession

The Westminster Confession’s treatment of the decree and providence gives a worked-out compatibilist account of human agency under an exhaustive divine decree.

### God’s exhaustive decree

Key affirmations:

- God has an all-encompassing, eternal decree: “God from all eternity did, by the most wise and holy counsel of his own will, freely and unchangeably ordain whatsoever comes to pass” (WCF 3.1).
- This decree is grounded solely in God’s good pleasure, not foreseen conditions: election and reprobation are “according to the counsel of his will” and “not for any foresight of faith, or good works” (3.5).
- The decree is simple and eternal; what God decrees, he will infallibly bring to pass in history (5.1).

This is exhaustive: nothing falls outside the scope of God’s ordination. That includes the entire history of sin and suffering.

### Secondary causes and providence

The Confession immediately guards against a fatalistic reading by its doctrine of means.

- God executes his decree “in his works of creation and providence” (3.1; 5.1).
- In providence, God “ordereth them to fall out, according to the nature of second causes, either necessarily, freely, or contingently” (5.2).
- God’s providence ordinarily works “through” means, not apart from them (5.3).

So:

- **Primary causality**: God as first cause ordains and concurs with all that comes to pass.
- **Secondary causality**: Created agents (human, angelic, physical) act according to their natures and powers; their actions are real causes with genuine efficacy.

The Confession sharply distinguishes God’s universal concursus from his moral relation to sin:

- God’s providence “extendeth itself even to the first fall, and all other sins of angels and men, and that not by a bare permission, but such as hath joined with it a most wise and powerful bounding, and otherwise ordering and governing of them, in a manifold dispensation, to his own holy ends” (5.4).
- Yet “the sinfulness thereof proceedeth only from the creature, and not from God” who, “being most holy and righteous, neither is nor can be the author or approver of sin” (5.4; echoed in 3.1).

So God’s ordination of sinful acts is not bare non-interference, but sovereign ordering; the evil as evil, however, is located solely in the disordered will of the creature.

### Compatibilist human freedom

Human freedom in Westminster is not libertarian indeterminism, but voluntariness under moral and metaphysical constraints.

- Human actions are free when they proceed “from the liberty of [the] will, which is neither forced, nor, by any absolute necessity of nature, determined to good or evil” (9.1).
- After the fall, man “hath wholly lost all ability of will to any spiritual good… being dead in sin… is not able, by his own strength, to convert himself, or to prepare himself thereunto” (9.3).
- Regenerate persons are “made willing by his grace” (10.1) and yet act most freely (effectual calling and sanctification do not coerce but renew the will).

The structure is compatibilist:

- **Metaphysically**, every act falls under God’s unchangeable decree and providential ordering (3.1; 5.1).
- **Psychologically**, acts are free when they flow from the agent’s own desires and character, without external compulsion.
- **Morally**, responsibility attaches because the will is the immediate principle of action; the agent does what he most wants to do, even though his desires are themselves fallen (or renewed) under God’s sovereign ordering.

Thus Westminster denies:

- That freedom requires the power of contrary choice in the libertarian sense.
- That God’s determining foreordination “violence[s] the will of the creatures” or “take[s] away the liberty or contingency of second causes, but rather establish[es] it” (3.1).

## Application to the problem of evil

### God ordains evil without being its author

Using this framework, a Reformed account addresses the problem of evil by several coordinated distinctions.

First, God’s decree of sinful events and his will as to sin are not univocal.

- God **wills** that certain sins occur as elements within his wise plan (decretive will).
- God **abhors** these same acts in terms of his moral law (preceptive will).
- The same event can be willed by God and by a creature under different descriptions and for different ends: God ordains Joseph’s sale into slavery for saving many lives; the brothers intend it for envy and harm.

Second, the sinfulness of an act inheres in the secondary cause, not in the first cause.

- God concurs in the act’s existence and ordering; without his sustaining power, no act could occur.
- The **moral defect**—the privation of right order, the disordered end and motive—is entirely in the creature’s will.
- Westminster’s insistence that God’s relationship to sin is “not by a bare permission” preserves sovereignty, while locating guilt exclusively in the created will.

Third, compatibilist freedom suffices for moral responsibility.

- Human beings sin because they want to sin, not because they are forced.
- Even though their desires fall under God’s decree and providence, their willing is spontaneous and expressive of their own character; they are judged for what they love and choose.
- The demand that responsibility requires libertarian ability-to-do-otherwise is rejected as an unscriptural philosophical standard imposed on God.

### Answering the evidential and existential aspects

On this account:

- **Logically**, the set {God is omnipotent; God is perfectly good; evil exists} is coherent because:
    - God may have morally sufficient reasons, often hidden to us, for ordaining that particular evils occur as means to greater goods (revelation of justice and mercy, union with Christ’s sufferings, eschatological glory).
    - Those goods include not only “soul-making,” but especially the manifestation of God’s attributes in redemptive history.
- **Metaphysically**, there is no rival principle of evil; evil is parasitic on good, a privation in the wills and actions of creatures sustained by God but misdirected by them.
- **Existentially**, God is not a distant architect of a tragic system; in Christ he enters history, assumes a true human nature, and, under that nature, suffers and endures the full weight of creaturely evil; yet even the crucifixion is presented as both a wicked act of men and the central event of God’s “definite plan and foreknowledge.”

Thus the Reformed, Westminster-guided account maintains an exhaustive decree and real human responsibility, while denying that God is the author of sin by distinguishing his holy, purposive ordination of all events from the creaturely defect that constitutes sin’s moral evil.

## Clarifying the Transcendental Strategy

The transcendental move is not a theodicy that supplies God’s reasons, nor a probabilistic defense that balances goods against evils. It is an argument about the **preconditions of the intelligibility** of the very discourse in which the problem of evil is framed.

A transcendental argument asks: given some datum that we cannot deny (for example, that we make moral judgments, or that we experience certain events as objectively evil), what must be true for that datum to be possible and intelligible? In Reformed form, this is sharpened into a claim about the **inescapable dependence of moral normativity and rational evaluation on the triune God** who speaks in Scripture.

So the focus is not: “Can we show that God has good reasons for allowing this evil?” but: “What must reality be like such that ‘this is evil and not merely disliked’ is even a coherent, rational judgment?”

## The Transcendental Premise Stated Step by Step

### Starting datum: moral judgments and the recognition of evil

We begin from the following features of our experience:

- We make and cannot escape **moral judgments** that purport to be more than expressions of preference (“torturing children for fun is wrong, even if a culture approves it”).
- In the face of horrors we experience not merely pain or dislike, but an intuition of **objective moral outrage**: “this ought not to be.”
- In raising the problem of evil, critics treat “evil” as a **real, objective defect** in the world that counts evidentially against a good God.

Call this complex fact: **objective-seeming moral experience**.

### The transcendental analysis of this datum

The question then is: what must be true of reality if such objective-seeming moral experience is to be:

- genuinely **objective** (not reducible to taste or emotion),
- **normative** (it binds, even against our desires),
- and **rationally authoritative** (something we can appeal to in arguments, including arguments against God)?

The transcendental claim is that:

- Objective, binding, rationally authoritative morality presupposes:
  
  - A **personal, absolute lawgiver** whose nature is the standard of good and whose will is universally binding.
  - A **created order** in which creatures are teleologically ordered to ends that are good by that standard.
  - **Human rational and moral faculties** that are designed to track such moral truths (even if corrupted).
  - An ultimate **moral eschatology** in which justice and the good are not accidental but consummated.

From within a Reformed Trinitarian framework, these conditions are met in the **triune God**:

- The Father as creator and moral governor.
- The Son as the Logos in whom the order and telos of creation subsist and through whom redemption reorients fallen creatures to their proper end.
- The Spirit as the one who illuminates and convicts, sustaining any genuine moral awareness even in rebels.

Formally, the transcendental premise is:

- **If** there are objective, binding, rationally authoritative moral judgments and real evils,
- **then** the ontological and epistemic preconditions just listed must obtain,
- and these preconditions are only coherently grounded in the triune God revealed in Scripture.

## From Premise to Conclusion

### Negative conclusion: internal critique of the atheist problem of evil

Once that premise is in place, the argument runs:

- The atheist or agnostic critic, by pressing the problem of evil, implicitly relies on:
  
  - The existence of **objective moral facts** (“this suffering is genuinely unjust, not merely disliked”).
  - The **rational authority** of such facts to count as evidence against a hypothesis about reality (the existence of a good, omnipotent God).

- But on a non-theistic metaphysic—where reality is ultimately impersonal, non-teleological, and contingent:

  - Moral “oughts” reduce to evolved preferences, social contracts, or subjective attitudes.
  - Normativity loses its objective, binding character; nothing in the impersonal substrate of the universe can generate genuine obligation.

top_exam_questions.question: You appeal to Augustine’s privation theory of evil. Explain in detail how privatio boni functions in Augustine’s doctrine of creation and providence, and then show how you would integrate that with your insistence that evil is "real" and not merely illusory.
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Historical and Metaphysical Setting

Augustine’s **privatio boni** is not a marginal idea but a structural axiom in his doctrine of God, creation, sin, and providence. It arises from two primary commitments:

- The absolute goodness, simplicity, and aseity of God, such that nothing evil can be in God or be directly created by him.
- The ex nihilo character of creation, such that every creature, as creature, is dependent, finite, and therefore mutable.

Within this framework, Augustine must explain how there can be what Scripture calls “evil” without positing either a rival evil substance or a defect in God’s creative act. Privation is his metaphysical instrument for doing this.

## Privation and the Doctrine of Creation

### Ontological goodness of creation

For Augustine, Genesis 1’s “very good” is ontological before it is moral.

- Every creature is good by virtue of existing as a participation, analogically, in God’s being and goodness.
- Degrees of being correspond to degrees of goodness: more being, more goodness; less being, less goodness.

Thus:

- God creates only good; nothing God positively brings into being is evil.
- Creaturely limitation and finitude are not themselves evil; they are simply the mark of being a creature rather than God.

### Evil as defect, not as substance

Against Manichaean dualism, Augustine insists:

- Evil is not an independent substance or co-eternal principle.
- Evil is a **privation** of a due good in a good nature; that is, a lack where fullness or right order ought to be.

Paradigmatic examples:

- Blindness is not a positive “thing” but the absence of sight where sight is due.
- Injustice is the will’s failure to be ordered to God, a missing rectitude of love, not a positive essence.

Applied to creation:

- Created natures, as such, remain good; what we call “evil in creation” is always some disorder, corruption, or deficiency in those natures relative to their created ends.
- Corruptio non tollit totum: corruption never annihilates the goodness of the nature; it parasitically distorts it.

In a Reformed idiom: Augustine’s schema underwrites the claim that “God saw all that he had made, and behold, it was very good,” even while acknowledging the radical subsequent fallenness of the world.

## Privation and Providence

### God’s causality and evil’s “non-cause”

Providentially, Augustine insists on two truths:

- God is the first cause of all that exists and all that occurs.
- God is not the author or cause of evil.

Privation theory enables him to hold these together by distinguishing:

- God as cause of the **being and natural goodness** of all things.
- Evil as a **defect in secondary causes**, located especially in the created will, which God permits but does not positively cause.

In willing and doing evil:

- The act as act (the exercise of power, movement of the will) is good as a natural actuality sustained by God.
- The moral evil lies in the lack of right order, the missing rectitude of love and intention that ought to inform that act.

God’s concurrence sustains every act as being; he does not infuse the disordered lack that constitutes its sinfulness. That lack has no efficient cause in the strict sense; it is a falling away, a defectus, of a mutable will from its proper rule.

### Permission and ordering

Providence, for Augustine, is not merely general conservation but also wise ordering of all events to God’s ends.

- God **permits** creaturely defects of will and their consequences; this permission is a positive volition in God, yet the defect itself remains a creaturely failure, not a divine product.
- God **orders** even these defects and the harms they generate toward greater goods: manifestation of justice, mercy, patience, and the glory of redemption.

Privation is crucial here:

- Because evil has no independent being, God can sovereignly encompass and overrule it without being morally tainted by it.
- In providence God “uses” evils as conditions or occasions for greater goods, while the evil itself remains a parasitic deficiency rather than a rival reality.

## Integrating Privation with the “Reality” of Evil

The risk with privatio boni is misunderstanding it as a denial of evil’s reality, collapsing it into an “illusion” theory. To avoid that, several clarifications are necessary.

### Different senses of “real”

Evil is **not real**:

- As a positive substance or essence.
- As something created or willed by God as such.
- As an ontological counter-principle to goodness.

Evil is **real**:

- As an objectively existing defect, disorder, and misalignment in the acts and states of real creatures.
- As a genuinely causal factor in history at the level of secondary causes (e.g., a tyrant’s decision, a corrupted environment).
- As that which truly damages created goods: bodies, relationships, institutions, and, above all, the relation of creatures to God.

Thus:

- To say “evil is privation” is not to say “evil is only in our heads” or “evil is merely a semantic construction.”
- Rather, it locates evil in the actual absence or twisting of determinate goods that ought to be present in the objective order of creation.

### Against illusionism

An illusion-based theodicy tends to say that what appears evil is, in reality, good when properly understood; evil is a misperception. Augustine’s position is sharply different:

- Many things we judge “evil” are indeed good when rightly considered (e.g., finite limitation, certain sufferings ordered by God for discipline).
- But sin, injustice, idolatry, cruelty, and the decay resulting from them are not simply misperceived goods; they are genuine deprivations of creaturely flourishing as measured by God’s law.

In other words:

- The **ontological status** of evil is privative, but the **moral and experiential character** of evil is fully real, and Scripture’s laments, curses, and judgments reflect that realism.
- Christ’s cross and resurrection presuppose the non-illusory reality of sin and death: what is destroyed and overcome is not a mirage but a real distortion of God’s good creation.

### Reformed integration

Within a classic Reformed framework:

- Privatio boni guards God’s holiness and sovereignty by denying a positive metaphysical evil principle and locating sin in created wills and in the ordered structure of creation gone awry.
- The “reality” of evil is affirmed by:
  
    - Total depravity understood as pervasive disorder in every faculty, not annihilation of the imago Dei.
  
    - The real bondage of the will, corruption of the cosmos, and hostility of fallen powers.

- Providence includes both:
  
    - God’s righteous decree encompassing even evil acts as part of a single, wise plan.
  
    - God’s distinct moral will, revealed in law and gospel, which those same acts violate.

Privation language helps articulate how God can decree to permit and govern sinful acts without himself producing the privation that constitutes their sinfulness.

## Conclusion

Privatio boni functions in Augustine as a way of affirming that creation is wholly good in its being and that God is never the author of evil, while still allowing that evil is a real, objective privation and corruption in creatures that God permissively folds into his providential ordering and finally overcomes in Christ.

top_exam_questions.question: You assert that "autonomous reasoning is disqualified" from judging God. Define what you mean by autonomy here, and relate this to general revelation, the light of nature, and the legitimate use of reason affirmed in the Reformed confessions.
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Clarifying “autonomous reasoning”

By “autonomous reasoning” in this context I mean **reason that treats itself as its own final standard**, rather than as a created, dependent faculty that must submit to God’s revelation.

More precisely, **autonomy** here includes at least three elements:

- **Epistemic self-sufficiency**: the assumption that human reason, operating from within the created order and without normative dependence on God’s revelation, is competent to render ultimate judgments about God’s being, purposes, and ways.

- **Normative self-legislation**: the idea that human moral and rational standards are not only functionally but finally authoritative, such that God’s character and acts must be justified before those standards.

- **Illicit transcendence of the creaturely standpoint**: the claim, explicit or implicit, to occupy a “view from nowhere” from which the whole—including God—can be assessed, rather than acknowledging that all our cognition is that of finite, fallen creatures addressed by God.

Saying that autonomous reasoning is “disqualified” from judging God means: **creaturely reason, considered as self-norming and independent, has no right, competence, or jurisdiction to lord it over God, to demand that God conform to our independent criteria of goodness, justice, or rationality.** The problem of evil becomes illegitimate precisely at the point where it moves from asking, “How can we understand what God has revealed?” to, “God must justify himself to standards we devise apart from him.”

This denial of autonomy is not a denial of reason as such, but a denial of reason as ultimate.

## General revelation and the light of nature

Within a Reformed framework, there is a strong affirmation of **general revelation** and the **light of nature**.

- **General revelation**: God manifests himself in creation and providence so that his eternal power and divine nature are clearly perceived. This is objective revelation, not a human construction.

- **Light of nature**: all humans retain, as image-bearers, a natural awareness of God, of moral obligation, and of basic logical and moral principles. This light is genuine but not neutral; it is both clear and suppressed in unrighteousness.

The Reformed confessions hold:

- That the **works of creation and providence** reveal God truly and sufficiently to leave humanity without excuse.

- That even outside Scripture, there remains a **natural law** and a natural knowledge of God and of good and evil.

Thus, the confessional tradition sharply distinguishes between:

- **Reason as recipient of revelation**: a finite, derivative faculty addressed by God through both general and special revelation.

- **Reason as its own measure**: the autonomous posture, which either brackets or judges divine revelation by independent criteria.

General revelation and the light of nature therefore establish **real, though non-saving, knowledge of God and of moral reality**, but they do not authorize reason to function as a court of appeal above God.

## The legitimate use of reason in Reformed theology

The Reformed confessions do not endorse irrationalism. They assign reason a high and necessary, though subordinate, role.

Legitimate uses of reason include:

- **Receiving and ordering revelation**: Reason discerns, compares, and systematizes what God has revealed in Scripture and creation. It is the instrument by which we construct doctrine from the text of Scripture, always under Scripture’s normativity.

- **Natural theology within limits**: From the created order, reason can infer that there is one God, powerful, wise, and good, and can arrive at certain moral insights. But such knowledge is darkened by sin and is not salvific or normatively correcting of Scripture.

top_exam_questions.question: You claim that the cross is the turning point where God "finally defeats evil." How do you reconcile that with the ongoing presence of evil and suffering in history, and how would you situate the cross as God’s answer to evil within an already/not-yet eschatology and the broader covenantal storyline of Scripture?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Historical and Eschatological Framing

Within classic Reformed theology, the cross is not the temporal point at which evil ceases to exist, but the decisive redemptive-historical event in which evil’s ultimate defeat is juridically and covenantally secured. The New Testament consistently speaks of Christ’s work in a threefold temporal aspect:

- **Decisive past victory**: Christ “disarmed the rulers and authorities” and “triumphed over them” in the cross.
- **Present contested reign**: He now “must reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet.”
- **Future consummation**: The last enemy, death, “will be destroyed” at the resurrection and final judgment.

Already/not-yet eschatology follows from this structure. The “age to come” has already invaded this present evil age in Christ’s death and resurrection, but the old age is not yet abolished. The cross, therefore, is not the temporal extinction of evil but the once-for-all, covenantally binding judgment on evil and the inauguration of the new creation which will finally remove it.

## The Cross and the Ongoing Presence of Evil

The ongoing reality of evil is reconciled with the claim of decisive defeat by distinguishing several coordinated dimensions of Christ’s work.

- **Judicial accomplishment versus historical application**:  
  At the cross, the decisive forensic verdict is rendered: the penalty of sin is borne, Satan is cast out as accuser, and the world is judged. Yet the application of this verdict to persons, institutions, and creation unfolds in history through the Spirit’s work, the gospel mission, and providential government. There is no further redemptive price to be paid, but there is progressive historical realization.

- **Decisive dethronement versus residual activity**:  
  Satan’s power as a legal accuser and god of this age is broken; he stands condemned. Nevertheless, until the parousia he still acts as a defeated but active enemy, restrained and doomed yet not yet finally removed. Evil persists as the convulsions of a vanquished regime under judgment, not as a rival dominion with open future.

- **Inaugurated new creation versus groaning creation**:  
  Christ’s resurrection is the beginning of the new creation; the Spirit is the arrabōn, the down payment of the inheritance. Yet creation still groans, awaiting the revealing of the sons of God. The cross-resurrection event plants the irreversible principle of new life into a world still marked by decay, so that the old and new ages overlap.

Thus evil’s presence is not evidence that the cross failed, but that redemptive history is between victory and consummation.

## The Cross in the Already/Not-Yet Structure

Within inaugurated eschatology, the cross functions in several tightly related ways.

- **Already: decisive judgment and justification**:  
  - The cross is God’s public verdict against sin and evil; the judgment day is brought forward into history. Believers are already justified; condemnation is removed; the power of sin is broken.  
  - The kingdom is already present: Satan’s house is plundered, the strong man bound, and a people are transferred from the domain of darkness into Christ’s kingdom.

- **Not yet: visible separation and eradication**:  
  - The final separation of righteous and wicked, and the definitive excision of evil from the cosmos, remain future. Wheat and tares grow together until the harvest.  
  - The “not yet” includes the full deliverance of bodies from corruption, the removal of every tear, and the public vindication of God’s righteousness before all creatures.

In this framework, the cross is God’s answer to the *ground* and *destiny* of evil: its guilt is expiated for the elect, its power is broken, its future is sealed. What remains is the historical outworking of that verdict until the last enemy is destroyed.

## The Cross in the Covenantal Storyline

Within the covenantal structure of Scripture, the cross is the climactic resolution of the problem of evil introduced in Adam and carried forward through Israel.

### From Adam to Christ

- **Covenant of works and fall**:  
  Under Adam as federal head, evil enters not as an eternal principle but as covenantal disobedience with forensic and cosmic consequences: guilt, corruption, curse, death. The problem of evil is thus centrally a problem of broken covenant, not merely of metaphysical or moral anomaly.

- **Covenant of grace and typological judgments**:  
  God’s answer unfolds in promise and type: judgments (flood, exile) that partially restrain and expose evil, and sacrifices that symbolically address guilt but cannot finally remove it. Evil is both punished and yet permitted to continue for the sake of the unfolding promise.

- **Christ as second Adam and true Israel**:  
  In the cross, Christ as federal head bears the curse of the law, fulfills Israel’s covenant obligations, and triumphs over principalities. Evil is addressed at the covenantal root:  
    - The law’s condemning power is satisfied.  
    - The dominion of sin over Adamic humanity is broken via union with the crucified and risen Christ.  
    - The demonic powers that exploited human guilt are disarmed.

### Cross, Covenant, and Eschatological New Creation

The new covenant promised in the prophets is inaugurated in Christ’s blood. This involves:

- **New heart and Spirit**: the internal renovation that begins to conform human wills to God’s will, thus already diminishing evil’s moral reign in the covenant community.
- **New creation people**: a holy nation called to embody, in weakness and suffering, the cruciform victory of Christ over evil by overcoming evil with good.
- **New creation cosmos**: secured in principle by the resurrection of the covenant head, to be unveiled at his return when the curse is lifted.

The cross, then, is not an isolated answer to individual suffering; it is the covenantal hinge where the story moves from Adamic curse to eschatological blessing, from the old age dominated by sin and death to the new age in which righteousness dwells.

## The Cross and Present Suffering

Within this framework, present suffering is re-situated but not trivialized.

- **Punitive versus fatherly discipline**:  
  For those in Christ, suffering is no longer retributive wrath but fatherly discipline and conforming to Christ, though it may be materially indistinguishable from the world’s afflictions.

- **Participation in the cruciform pattern**:  
  The church’s present life is patterned after Christ’s: suffering now, glory later. The “not yet” is lived under the sign of the cross; evil still strikes, but cannot separate from God’s love or overturn his purposes.

- **Apologetic and doxological function**:  
  The cross shows that God has entered the depths of evil and suffering, bearing it and judging it from within history. The ongoing presence of evil is thereby placed under a revealed context: it is encompassed by a divine purpose already disclosed and guaranteed in Christ’s death and resurrection.

In sum, within an already/not-yet eschatology and the covenantal storyline, the cross is the once-for-all juridical defeat of evil and inauguration of the new creation, with evil’s final eradication reserved for the consummation when what was decisively won in Christ is universally and visibly applied.
